item.title: Content-Oblivious Trust and Safety Techniques: Results from a Survey of Online Service Providers
item.description: Authors: Pfefferkorn, Riana Abstract: Modern-day online services are plagued by various kinds of harmful content, from hate speech to terrorist propaganda to depictions of the sexual abuse of children, to name just a few. Regulators’ focus on content analysis overlooks the prevalence and utility of what this article calls content-oblivious techniques. This article presents the results of a survey about the trust and safety techniques employed by a group of online service providers, most of them communications services or services driven primarily by user-generated content.

item.title: The Law and Policy of Client-Side Scanning
item.description: Authors: Rosenzweig, Paul Published: August 2020 URL: https://www.lawfareblog.com/law-and-policy-client-side-scanning Abstract: The idea of Client-Side Scanning—which aims to develop systems to scan photographs and messages before they are sent or received by users—is attractive, but it has far too many technical, legal and policy uncertainties to be ripe for adoption at this time.
